item.title: How Perl CPAN Modules Are Updated in SUSE
item.description: Introduction Packages for SUSE distributions are built in the Open Build Service (OBS). In the devel:languages:perl repository we currently have over 3100 perl modules from CPAN. Not all of them land in the official SUSE distribution repositories though. openSUSE:Factory is the repository which tracks those packages. In there we currently have almost 1400 CPAN modules. There are too many CPAN uploads to all do them manually in OBS. So we have an automated process for updating.

item.title: Using OBS as a CI for Perl Modules
item.description: Introduction In my previous Building a Perl Module in OBS post I showed how you can build rpm packages in OBS from your perl module(s). Every commit on the main branch will trigger a new build. Now I will show how to automatically build the package from a GitHub Pull Request. It’s recommended to read the previous post first. For that I need to add an OBS Workflow. I need a GitHub Token, an OBS Token and a workflow YAML file.

item.title: Building a Perl Module in OBS
item.description: Introduction The Open Build Service is used to build all packages for the SUSE operating system family. It can also be used to build other package formats. In this post I want to show you how you can setup a project to build your perl module(s) in OBS. Some parts might not be that intuitive, so I documented everything with screenshots. In my next post I will show how you can setup your package to automatically build on pull requests.
